ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A disciplinary approach to "sound studies," and a survey of the ways to put under pressure "sound" and "studies" and what it means for an emerging field, to put the two together.
This course was a great introduction to Sound Studies. It was interesting discovering the different subfields and learning about ways of addressing sound outside of music theory and musicology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of the course is in its organization, structure, and this semester's iteration of classmate dynamics; I never felt lost for a second in spite of how sprawling the topics covered tend to be. The course could be improved by more overtly foregrounding in discussion people's individual interests and the utility of sound studies to their practice/work, i.e. an addition to each class where there's a tiny recap of what people find most interesting/difficult/salient, versus at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're an argument-driven thinker and into critical theory and philosophy as frameworks for approaching "sound," and you're willing to have your views challenged by articulate and diverse students, take the class. Do speak up and fumble; it makes the world go round, and Sound Studies, as dense as it gets at times, is no exception.
I think it indispensible to students in the humanities.
